: There was once a certain caribou.
: The caribou worked for a company and led a very busy life.
: Day after day, he went back and forth to the company, staring at his watch all the while.
: I didn't know caribou could get jobs.
: Or wear watches, for that matter.
smiles nostalgically and plays with her wristband.
: The caribou was troubled. However long and hard he worked, he found that the days only repeated themselves. No time left for himself, always felt weary. Poor thing.
: However, this caribou had a lover.
: She had beautiful long hair and eyes that seemed to carry a certain sorrow.

: "For being able to understand people's pain, you're a very kind person. But that's also why you wound yourself so deeply. Let us just be together like we always have been." - is what his lover said.
: The caribou's life was nothing but distress. But in the time he spent with his lover, he felt as if he was saved from all of it. With her, the caribou was happy.
: Then one morning, the caribou had overslept on a particularly important day, due to being so drowned in work.
comes back and sits, listening.
: He was running late when suddenly- his briefcase opened by itself and WOOSH!
: All his papers went flying out.
: He stood there and looked down at the papers, not sure what to do. He'd be late whether or not he bent down to pick them up.
: He then did so, sighing as he did.
: "Hello! You look troubled, hm?" He held his plump belly and spoke to the caribou cheerfully. "Need a hand?"
: "You appear to be burdened with great unhappiness."
: "You know, though, I could take away your unhappiness."
: ((Aaaaaaaand I have to go to sleep now.  Goodnight!))
: "Your horns." The rooster pointed to the two horns on the caribou's head. "So long as you have those horns, you will be sorrowful. That is to say, they are the source of your discontent."
: "Unhappiness is fear. Unhappiness is agony. Unhappiness is grief."
: "No person wants to feel these discontents. They wish to live the happiest life they can. Isn't that right? It's not a good thing to be unhappy."

"But who is it that creates this unhappiness? Unquestionably, it is you yourself who feels unhappy.
So couldn't we say, at least in a way, it is you yourself that makes unhappiness?"
: "So it is best that I remove your horns. In doing so, I will remove the discontent from your mind. And once you no longer feel unhappy, you will live happy forever."
: After that, the caribou was cheerful! He got plastic horns in place of his old ones. He hadn't a care in the world! He felt as if that depression was simply a bad dream.
: Not long after, he and his lover were on a date.
: He chattered on and on about his work, he always had something to say now that he was happy.
: And suddenly, she stopped him. Quietly so.
: "We shouldn't be together anymore." she said
: The caribou was confused, as she was never one to joke, quiet as she'd always been.
: "I don't know, either." she told him, tearfully so. "But you've changed somehow. You can't tell my pain anymore."
: She then told him goodbye, and left the table.
